symptoms.name: Umbilicated papules
symptoms.pattern: Firm, rounded, 2-5mm, pink or skin-colored, shiny surface. Can be single, multiple, or clustered. May have erythematous halo or be pediculated.

symptoms.name: Pruritus
symptoms.pattern: May or may not be present

symptoms.name: Eczema-like reaction
symptoms.pattern: Pink, rough, itchy skin around molluscum lesions. Can lead to scratching and spread of infection.

symptoms.name: Red and swollen bumps
symptoms.pattern: Molluscum bumps may become red and swollen, sometimes forming pus-filled pimples. This is usually a sign of the immune system fighting the virus.

symptoms.name: Pink-purple or white spots
symptoms.pattern: May appear after molluscum bumps go away and fade over time.

physical_findings: Dome-shaped, shiny bumps with a central dimple or whitish core
Lesions located anywhere on the skin except palms and soles (common sites: neck, armpits, sides of chest, thighs, buttocks, genitals, face)
BOTE sign (erythema, edema, crusting) indicating spontaneous regression
risk_factors: Contact with contaminated objects (towels, gym mats, razors)
Immunocompromised individuals (HIV, organ transplant recipients, pediatric cancer patients)

required: Characteristic clinical presentation of umbilicated papules
supportive: Skin biopsy (especially in immunocompromised patients or when diagnosis is uncertain)
Enzyme-linked immunoassays (ELISA) - used in research, not routine clinical practice
